text: Climate change creates feedback loops where warming triggers processes that cause even more warming. For example, when ice melts, darker surfaces absorb more heat, which causes further melting. Thawing permafrost releases greenhouse gases, which increase warming and cause more thawing. Forest dieback and ocean warming also reduce Earth‚Äôs ability to absorb carbon, making the problem worse.

text:
here are some ways to stop this:
üî• Top Ways to Stop Global Warming With Current Tech & Knowledge
Switch to Renewable Energy
Ditch coal, oil, and gas. Solar, wind, and hydro power are proven, scalable, and getting cheaper every year.

Electrify Transportation
Push electric vehicles (EVs), public transit, and bike infrastructure to cut down on fossil fuel use.

Energy Efficiency
Upgrade buildings, appliances, and industrial processes to waste less energy.

Protect and Restore Forests
Trees suck up CO‚ÇÇ ‚Äî protecting existing forests and reforesting degraded lands is a massive carbon sink.

Regenerative Agriculture
Farming methods that improve soil health, store carbon, and reduce emissions (no-till, cover crops).

Carbon Capture & Storage (CCS)
Tech that captures CO‚ÇÇ from power plants or the air and stores it underground or uses it in products.

Reduce Methane Emissions
Methane‚Äôs a powerful greenhouse gas ‚Äî fixing leaks in oil/gas systems and improving livestock management can help big time.

Shift to Plant-Based Diets
Animal agriculture is a major emitter; eating less meat can lower emissions and free up land.

Smart Urban Planning
Create walkable cities, green spaces, and better transit to reduce car dependency and urban heat islands.

Ban or Limit Single-Use Plastics
Plastics come from fossil fuels and their production + waste contribute to emissions.

Promote Circular Economy
Design products to last, repair, reuse, and recycle to cut down resource extraction and emissions.

Increase Public Awareness & Policy Pressure
Citizens pushing for climate policies and holding governments/corporations accountable.

Bottom Line
We have the tools ‚Äî what‚Äôs missing is political will and massive coordinated action. The tech isn‚Äôt sci-fi, it‚Äôs real and ready to roll. It‚Äôs on us to demand change and support the solutions.
